title: Long Term Ecological Research
section: Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers
text:
Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers
As part of the 2025-29 renewal proposal to the National Science Foundation the Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Network Office proposed an yearlong course to train early career researchers in synthesis work. Synthesis skills differ from primary research skills because synthesis requires a focus on collaboration as well as an increased emphasis on quantitative skills. Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers (SSECR) is that course and it will be first offered in fall of 2024 to a cohort of ~30 students (about 1 per LTER site). The course materials can be found at lter.github.io/ssecr though they will likely be under construction/revision until late 2024/early 2025.

NCEAS Roundtable (2024)
Invited to give a presentation at National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis (NCEAS) at the monthly “roundtable” presentation.

title: Multivariate Statistics 101
text:
Multivariate Background

Multivariate data have more variables (p) than observations (q)




I.e., more columns than rows

True of most ecology/evolution datasets





Differs from univariate statistics

Univariate explores variation in one variable
Multivariate explores variation in many variables (plus potential inter-relationships)

title: Multivariate Statistics 101
text:
Resampling Methods

Frequentist statistics uses distributions from theory






Resampling statistics uses distributions from data

title: Multivariate Statistics 101
text:
Theoretical Process

Take samples from data (i.e., “re-sample”)



Compare real observations to re-sampled groups




Evaluate significance

title: Multivariate Statistics 101
text:
Permutation Notes

Permutation methods are non-parametric

Because they don’t rely on a theoretical distribution






Permutation methods are flexible

Can assess standard & non-standard experimental designs
Handle high-dimensional data (more variables than observations)
